title: Correlative Electron Microscopy and Multi-isotope Mass Spectrometry Reveal Biological Longevity at Macromolecular, Organelle, Cell, and Tissue Scales
content: Aging is a biological process characterized by a gradual loss of cell function and increased risk for degenerative and metabolic diseases. While it is generally accepted that most brain neurons are not replaced during an animal’s lifetime, little is known about the longevity of cells in somatic organs. Similarly, while the turnover of organelles and protein complexes has been studied at length using bulk mass spectrometry approaches, we lack the understanding on the spatial distribution of protein and organelle longevity in animal models and in situ. Because of their longevity, long-lived biological structures – whether a post-mitotic cells (i.e., neurons) or a long-lived protein (i.e., histones) - are more likely to accumulate age-related damage that compromises cell function. Therefore, there is a need to create microscopy methods to quantify cell or macromolecular turnover in situ at the single cell level.
